page.title: 18LOCAL HISTORY-HOUSES
page.content: Our area is attractive and is fortunate to have several old houses,large and small and of varying dates. By far the most interesting house in the area and indeed in this part of Somerset is LYTE'S CARY.Lyte's Cary house was from the thirteenth to the eighteenth century the home of the Lyte family,from which of course it takes its name.There is a minstrels' gallery which has an open timber roof with angels.Swans and horses have been moulded on a plaster ceiling,more are outside a bay window. John Lyte and Edith Horsey had a son called Henry who made a garden here and wrote about it in a book called'LYTE'S HERBAL'.Lyte's Cary House was given to the National Trust by Sir Walter Jenner in 1948.
